displayed_text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: Looking at the first scan we did when we first started. The scan we did after enzalutamide. So then we’re back at sort of like this. It sort of looks like we’re staying on. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So things are still growing at a slow to moderate pace, I’d say. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh so yeah I, I, I’m always concerned about that but I don’t think it’s reflective of making it grow more. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Now we have seen folks you know stop the testosterone and PSA goes back down. Some of that elevation is related to, to stimulate production. Patient: Right. Doctor: So you know we’d like to see where, where we go with that. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh in terms of once we reboot to be well again. The uh the problem we face is you know looking at the trials there are sort of two levels of looking at what’s available next.

Patient: Thank you. (laughs) Doctor: Um but that’s an option where… Patient: I’m working on year seventy-four so I’m hanging in there. Doctor: Doing pretty darn good. Um but I think the the downside of that trial is you’re here all the time, but the plus side is you’re getting you know the chemo is a standard and the vitamin C we’ll see what happens so. Patient: Yeah. If I need to cancel that trip… Doctor: Okay. Patient: …to S___, it’s a done deal. Doctor: Okay - No. N - honestly you gotta get off Casodex for six weeks anyways… Patient: Oh, okay. Doctor: …so the timing is perfect. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Why I wanted you in here is one, we have a plan in place…

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the last 2 years (1 year but less: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the last 2 years (1 year but less than 2 years ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.3 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::3 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.neutral: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::neutral

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.disagree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::disagree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.disagree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.neutral: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::neutral

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.agree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::agree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.agree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::agree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::agree

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.Some college: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Some college

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Black or African American: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Black or African American

displayed_text: Patient: Right. Doctor: Can I tell you how much that’s gonna increase the fifty/fifty odds? No. Can I tell you that that’s the most aggressive thing we can do for this cancer right now anywhere in the world? Yes. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: It’s what you know basically how I take care, how I try to take care of guys like you who are young and I want to hit the cancer really hard. Patient: Right. Doctor: So your choice basically is radiation with hormones or if you want to try a super sort of therapy, with chemo, super hormones, we can do that. Patient: Okay. Family Member 1: Yes, super hormones uh for what duration? Doctor: We, uh I give them for three months for four doses of chemo three weeks apart. Family Member 1: And let me ask you um, Are there any treatments that you use with the PSMA that targeted those cells, um? Doctor: Um yes, so, so, you’re talking about like PSMA radionuclide therapy and um right now there are a couple of clinical trials in the United States for guys who have failed hormone therapy. There are also – um you can do that – I’ve sent probably; uh I’ve sent twelve guys over to Germany to get that therapy in the last eighteen months uh you know specifically to try and like avoid like hormone therapy or something. What I can tell you is in this setting that therapy is not curing anybody. So if you’d asked me eighteen months ago, I would have said sure, let’s send you over there. What I’ve learned in the last eighteen months is that nobody I’ve sent over has been cured by that therapy, and uh I don’t consider it worthwhile right now. Family Member 1: Okay, and then the other question was - I don’t know if this makes a difference or not, Do we have a Gleason score of the margins that were left? Doctor: So it’s and uh irrelevant and undoable because you know the therapy he received, uh we wouldn’t uh it’s not scored.

Family Member: Now, you said immuno--- Doctor: So, the other thing that’s a little further back in time Patient: But, did you say multiple “harms?” Doctor: Hormones. Patient: Hormones. Okay. Doctor: So, one of the trials is you get -- Patient: Yeah. Doctor: a second line hormone versus a second line hormone plus this new PARP drug versus this PARP drug. So, Patient: But, that will be a decision we will make together. Doctor: Yeah, and that’s a coin flip between all those three. Um. That’s kind of a random trial. So, we can talk about that. Um. The immune therapy story is an earlier - it’s still in it’s earlier phases, but people are starting to think, if you have these mutations, you’re making abnormal things on the - in the cell, and that might – and that’s what kind of gets the immune system excited, something that looks weird. And, maybe you would respond better – ‘cuz right now when we give these new immune drugs, they work really well for some cancers Kidney cancer, melanoma, lung cancer. They don’t work very well for prostate cancer in just the general population. So, we’re trying to --- we think they’re good drugs, but we’re trying to figure out what’s the best way to use those. Patient: They might be usable with somebody with the genetic mutation. Doctor: Right. That’s what they’re – we have some kind of preliminary evidence, that’s true. No one’s done a huge study yet to, to prove that. What we were – I told you about this study we’re trying to do which is, we had two men who got one of our testosterone studies, responded, stayed on the drug for about a year, came off the drug, got some other things, and then got an immune therapy trial, with the expectation that the, uh, the immune therapy doesn’t work really well. But, both of those guys had unbelievable response; a ninety-nine percent drop in their PSA, disease disappeared. So, we’re not exactly sure, but what they both had in common was that they got testosterone. So, our, our, one of our trials is looking at that combination. Does the testosterone change the cell surface or whatever? So, we can talk about that, too, but

Family Member: Right. Doctor: So I’ve got to find out about that. Those are the two I’m going to look at. Okay? Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: And then I’m going to look at what is the Xtandi going to cost us, and, you know, hopefully within the next two days, I’ll have the answer to all that. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Okay? Family Member: Okay. Doctor: The insurance part may take a little bit longer because, uh, I can’t, I don’t know enough about insurance to predict. It’s crazy. It’s silly. But that’s, you know. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: But the drug’s like twelve thousand dollars a month. Family Member: Hum. You said one was going to be coming out on the market soon? Doctor: Oh. I’m sorry. I jumped, I jumped around. So, uh, I jumped to the radium thing. But there’s another trial that’s coming up. Family Member: Maybe put that down so you can focus some again on the radium study.

Patient: Alright. Doctor: Have fun. Enjoy the weather. Patient: Let’s see. Six weeks is going to put us in middle of July? Family Member: Right. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: End of July. Family Member: So what is – can he take anything to help him sleep? Like natural? Doctor: You can try melatonin. Family Member: Melatonin. That’s right. Doctor: I suggest stop drinking at seven p.m. and you’ll be a miracle. You won’t even get up that much. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Then you’ll say, oh, my, gosh, I’m awake and I didn’t get up.

Healthcare Professional: They are moving. Doctor: Yes. Healthcare Professional: That one moved that way. Doctor: So just uh can you put us on mute a minute? Thank you. Patient: Pardon? Doctor: Does your ex know? Patient: Oh, yeah. Doctor: Okay. You know well when you’re on chemo she’s going to know, so. Patient: Yeah. Uh, I really hate the idea of losing my hair. Doctor: You’ll probably just get thinning. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Because you have a lot of hair.

Patient: Not yet, no. Yes, I saw her, but I haven’t talked with her. Doctor: Okay, blood pressure’s high today. What’s that about? Patient: I think rushing here. I hope. Doctor: Any new, new allergies? Patient: No. Doctor: Still taking adult aspirin twice a day. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: Uh, lovastatin forty milligrams a day Patient: Mm, hmm Doctor: The probiotic once a day? Patient: Yep. Doctor: Your calcium with vitamin D one a day?

Patient: Right. Doctor: So, for us to think about this trial as an option for you, we would have to restart the Xtandi – Patient: Uh, huh. Doctor: Check your PSA in a couple weeks and knowing that your ARV seven positive, it’s very likely that the PSA will still be higher. (Pause) Patient: Okay. Doctor: It’s different. It’s new. There is buzz out there, but the bottom line in prostate cancer is we don’t know how well these drugs work, if at all. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, it has less side effects than chemotherapy but has more risks than chemotherapy because if we do turn on your immune system really good, attack you, you could be bad. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay? Family Member: That’s if it ends up going bad versus -- uh, activated immune system. Doctor: We often use steroids, and we try to sort of dampen it – Family Member: Okay.

Patient: Yes. Right. Doctor: all guys that are getting older are at risk for a hernia so don’t do that. Patient: I won’t. I won’t do that no more. Doctor: Okay and when you go home please take the Norco. Patient: I will. I like what you said on this. I definitely want it at night. That’s I’m not gonna miss that one. Doctor: Then you’re gonna rest. Patient: Yes and I like that. During the day see what. Doctor: Yeah, you just see how it, and then, you know, when you take this don’t drive, Patient: Right. Right Doctor: don’t do, I mean and literally don’t drive heavy machinery. Patient: Yeah, I don’t. Doctor: The number of times I’ve had to say that. Wait, so I can’t go out there and work on the tractor? Patient: Right. No.

Patient: It’s open-ended . I wanted Doctor: There might come a time that we might do something perfectly capable… and at that point Patient: Okay. Perfect. Fine. Doctor: Alrighty. Take this with you. It’s the consent form. The next step on my part would be to contact the study team. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Either he or his scheduling staff. And we’ll be in touch with you by telephone. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay. in scheduling your appointment and ask you the possible – he maybe to see this Friday. But I think if he can see you this week, than Patient: Okay. Doctor: a lot of information and try to look over that consent form. Patient: I will. Thank you. Doctor: Alright. I like this plan.

Family Member: You went out on the deck. Patient: No. I’m talking about walking. I’m not talking about that now. Family Member: Oh. Okay. Right. I just wanted to clarify. Patient: But I went out to, uh, to see how, how to walk because sometimes it was difficult walking especially with this leg here. And, uh, I don’t, I don’t know, I had a whole lot of pep in my step- Doctor: Okay. Patient: - going down and coming back, and, uh, my daughter said you don’t seem like you feel anything. I said, no, I feel pretty good there. And, uh, so I do have those particular days, but then I have those days as well. I said, oh, man, when this day going to be over with so I can go to bed tonight Doctor: Is that because of pain that those days are hard for you? Patient: Sometimes it’s, it’s pain, but a lot of the areas that I wasn’t haven’t pain in, uh, not much anymore. My heel on my left side was having a lot of pain that I think I had shared, and, uh, I still have some if I go and overdo it, but other than that, no, my shoulders every now and then. My biggest challenge now is, is getting a good night’s sleep. Doctor: Okay. Patient: And that’s because I’ve tried a number of different ways on how to sleep in the bed. I, I have these pillows that I prop up with a long pillow there, to try to lean up against the back of it so, I, you know, my back is up against the pillow. It works some nights. Some nights it doesn’t work. Doctor: Okay. And so you’re having trouble falling asleep or is it that you fall asleep and then you, you’re waking up with-? Patient: Well, I wake back up. And sometimes if, uh, you know how you try to get in a comfortable position? It’s trying to find that comfortable position for that night.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: We might find two, three spots. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Perhaps lymph nodes, which could be hidden or camouflaged with a conventional CT scan. But everything up to three we will be able to do stereotactic radiation for each of the three metastases. Because more than three then we feel it’s beyond the scope of this trial, it also becomes um less feasible and less practical to target five, six, seven spots. Patient: So at the beginning of the trial you’ll do that scan and that will determine whether I’ll stay in the trial if it’s three or less? Doctor: I believe that the PSMA Pet scan is optional. It’s something that they will discuss with you- Patient: Okay. Doctor: and you may opt out. For example, if you had say I just want to focus on treating that area let’s just do it Patient: Okay. Doctor: now one of the things that about the trial is that it’s randomized. Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: What does a randomized trial mean and in this particular case what are people are being randomized too. Randomized means that a computer and then essentially flips a coin and is random, very random in group A and group B of the clinical trial.

Patient: No. Well, they were having a problem getting my- Doctor: Yes. Exactly. Well, the problem is, it’s just this bad cycle you’re in. You know? Then you’re tired. It comes around and around. Family Member: Yeah just make better choices. Doctor: Okay. Glad we had this conversation about your diabetes in a prostate cancer clinic, but that’s actually number one. Doctor: Plus, you know, you’re getting that stupid, you know, Lupron shot from us, or, all the time. Patient: Right. Doctor: Are we the ones that give it to you? Family Member: Yeah. Patient: Yeah. K___ gives it. Doctor: Yeah. From us. I’m like why did I think it wasn’t us? Oh, it’s us. And you know we make your diabetes like even worse. So I feel partly responsible. I’m just trying to make sure you stay healthy. No carbs. Patient: Okay. Then, we’re going to see you, see you in six weeks? Doctor: That’s it. Enjoy yourself.

Doctor: Uh. It’s pretty nonspecific. Your aspirin puts you at a higher risk for like various Doctor: -things, such as bleeding. Patient: Okay. Should I stop that? Doctor: No. I mean, my sense is you’ve been on it for some reason. I, but, we didn’t start it, right? Patient: Yeah, yeah. My, um, primary doctor did. Doctor: So, you know, that would be the person to check. Patient: Okay. Doctor: with as to sort of, why am I doing this? Patient: Alright. Okay. Doctor: Um. Other questions you guys have? Patient: No. Family Member: The, um, who is the, is it a Hospital B’s, um, clinical trial or is it a combination with another company or? Doctor: Um. So, the phase one
